FacilityName: Clear Creek CSD Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Clear Creek CSD has instituted a Risk Management Program for their water treatment facility, Clear Creek CSD Water Treatment Plant, as required by Federal Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Program regulations (40 CFR Part 68).  The Risk Management Program identifies the equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with Regulated Substances (RS's) handled at this facility in excess of Federal threshold quantities; describes the structured assessment of hazards which was conducted to assess possible effects on employees and offsite public and environmental receptors; provides the results of an offsite consequences analysis; defines a prevention program, emergency response program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probability and magnitude of accidental releases of RS's; and establishes a schedule and responsibilities for implementation of mitigation measures and auditing of program elements.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is being filed as required by ARP regulations in order to report the elements of the current Risk Management Program and to satisfy the requirement for a 2019 5-year update.  



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Clear Creek CSD provides water supply and distribution to portions of Shasta County south of the City of Redding.  Its water treatment plant is located at Paige Bar Rd., 1 mile below Whiskeytown Dam, Redding, CA in Shasta County, and uses chlorine for disinfection in quantities greater than the Federal threshold quantity limit.  The facility is located above the base of Clair A. Hill Dam forming Whiskeytown Reservoir, in Whiskeytown - Shasta - Trinity National Recreation Area.  There are no full-time employees at this site.  Additionally, the chlorine building is separated from the rest of the water treatment plant by several hundred feet and is approximately 75 feet lower in elevation that the main treatment building.  Operators visit the treatment plant on a regular schedule and the c

hlorine room as needed.  They also respond to alarm conditions. 



Chlorine is received in ton containers by truck, handled with an electric hoist, and stored on ton container scales or trunions inside the building.  The chlorine is injected into the water stream to disinfect it.  Pressurized chlorine gas within a ton container is reduced to vacuum at a vacuum regulator valve mounted directly onto the ton container's gas valve.  From there, the chlorine under vacuum is metered through rate valves and rotameters, and drawn into water solution by the passage of pressurized water through an injector.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



It is the policy of Clear Creek CSD that the receipt, storage and handling of chlorine at its facility be done in a manner which meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of releases of chlorine to the atmosphere, in order to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public, and the environment.  In order to accomplish this goal, Clear Creek CSD has gathered safety information on chlorine and on the process, equipment and procedures involving chlorine; performed a structured assessment of hazards of the process and external events which might affect the process; performed an offsite consequences analysis of defined release scenarios; established a written program for prevention and mitigation of releases; and established a written emergency response program coordinated with emergency response agencies.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS



General accidental release prevention programs instituted by Clear Creek CSD are categorized as administrative (management) programs; procedures, training, and engineering controls; PPE; and emergency response programs. Clear Creek CSD has instituted a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program meeting Cal / OSHA requirements at GISO 5189 covering its disinfection process.  This constitutes the general accidental releas

e prevention program for Clear Creek CSD's operations.  The program and document management procedures included in the PSM Program are used as the management system for the Risk Management Program.



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS



Release prevention steps specific to chlorine have been identified and implemented.  These include, among other things, creation of numerous facility-specific operation procedures with check boxes for completion of critical steps.  A second set of chlorinators for winter use (lower maximum capacity) has been installed.  The leak detectors have been replaced with newer units.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no reportable accidents involving chlorine at this facility within the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Clear Creek CSD's Emergency Response Program applicable to chlorine has been coordinated with Shasta County Department of Environmental Health and the Shasta Cascade Hazardous Materials Response Team (SCHMRT).  These are the local agencies responsible for hazardous materials inventory reporting and release response coordination.  Clear Creek CSD is incorporated into the Shasta County Area Plan.  Clear Creek CSD is a non-responding facility per 29CFR 1910.38 and GISO 3220.  It's response consists of notification of SCHMRT via 911 and evacuation of persons on site to designated assembly areas upwind of the released gas. SCHMRT has received Clear Creek CSD's "B" repair kit which it will maintain.  It will bring a kit and any additional needed equipment if a response is needed.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the process hazard analysis which Clear Creek CSD committed to accomplish have been completed or are in progress.  Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or as a result of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.
